title: Hooks
name: Hooks
description:
Here are the standard hooks that fire (in order) on the bootstrap of your Reactium application.

Hook Description
init Called before all other hooks on startup.
dependencies-load Called while application dependencies are loaded.
service-worker-init Called while service worker is loaded.
zone-defaults Called while rendering zone default components are loaded.
store-create Called while Redux store is being created.
store-created Called after Redux store is created.
plugin-dependencies Called before loading runtime plugins.
plugin-init Called to initiate plugin registration.
routes-init Called to initiaze React router
register-route Called for each route that is registered
data-loaded Called on route load to pre-load data
plugin-ready Called after all plugins registration callbacks have completed
component-bindings Called to sibling React components and their DOM element bindings
app-bindpoint Called to define the main application bind point.
app-redux-provider Called to define the Redux provider component
app-router Called to provide the React router component
app-ssr-mode Called to make the application aware of server-side rendering mode
app-boot-message Called to define the javascript console boot message
app-ready Called when the application is being bound or hydrated by ReactDOM

title: Server.AppBindings
name: Server.AppBindings
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines React bind pointes in markup.

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app binding registry object.

binding.description: string name of component to bind directly if possible (must be in a webpack search context in reactium-config)
ordinary markup that React will use to bind the app.

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.AppGlobals
name: Server.AppGlobals
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines window globals to be defined in template. Will also define global for nodejs (useful for Server-Side-Rendering).

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app globals registry object.

global.description: The property name that will be added to window (for browser) or global (for nodejs).
any javascript value that can be serialized for use in a script tag
optional different value for the server global, useful when value should be used differently on the server code

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.AppHeaders
name: Server.AppHeaders
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines html head tags (exluding stylesheet). Use this hook to register/unregister tags as strings. Note: if using Server Side Render and react-helmet, this is often unnecessary to do.

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app header registry object.

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.AppScripts
name: Server.AppScripts
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines javascript files to be loaded.

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app scripts registry object.

script.description: Place the script tag in the footer if true
Place the script tag above the body if true

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.AppSnippets
name: Server.AppSnippets
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines snippets of code to be added to document in their entirety.

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app snippets registry object.

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.AppStyleSheets
name: Server.AppStyleSheets
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Defines css files to be loaded.

Parameter.description: express request object
Server app styles registry object.

stylesheet.description: the src of the stylesheet or resource
callback passed the request object, and returns true or false if the css should be included

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.Middleware
name: Server.Middleware
description: Used to register or unregister express middleware.

Parameter.description: Server express middleware registry object.

examples.title: reactium-boot.js

title: Server.ResponseHeaders
name: Server.ResponseHeaders
description: On html template responses on server, this hook is called when HTTP headers are added to the response. Both sync and async hook is called.

Parameter.description: object with key pairs (header name => header value)
Node/Express request object
Node/Express response object

title: Server.ServiceWorkerAllowed
description: Called on server-side during service-worker-allowed middleware. Used to define the HTTP response header "Service-Worker-Allowed". By default, this header will allow the document root, "/". Both sync and async version called.

Parameter.description: with property 'Service-Worker-Allowed' (case sensitive) and its value.
Node/Express request object
Node/Express response object

name: Server.ServiceWorkerAllowed

title: Server.afterApp
name: Server.afterApp
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Called after other Server hooks.

Parameter.description: express request object
ReactiumBoot Server object.

title: Server.beforeApp
name: Server.beforeApp
description: Before index.html template render for SPA template (both Front-end and Server-Side Render). Called before other Server hooks.

Parameter.description: express request object
ReactiumBoot Server object.

title: app-bindpoint
name: app-bindpoint
description: Called after plugin and routing initialization to define the DOM element used for mounting the Single-Page application (SPA). By default, the application will bind to document.getElementById('router'), but this can be changed with this hook. This is related to the HTML template artifacts left by the server-side Server.AppBindings hook. async only - used in front-end application only

Parameter.description: context.appElement MUST be an HTMLElement where your React appliation will bind to the DOM.

appElement.description: DOM element to bind to - by default document.getElementById('router').

title: app-boot-message
name: app-boot-message
description: Called during application binding, this minor hook will allow you to change the format of the of the front-end Javascript console message indicating application start. async only - used in front-end application only

title: app-context-provider
name: app-context-provider
description: Called after app-bindpoint to define any React context providers, using the Reactium.AppContext registry.

title: app-ready
description: The final hook run after the front-end application has bee bound or hydrated. After this point, the all hooks are runtime hooks.
name: app-ready

Parameter.description: If the app is in server-side rendering mode (SSR) true is passed to the hook.

title: app-router
name: app-router
description: Called after app-redux-provider to define the registered Router component (i.e. Reactium.Component.register('Router'...)). After this hook, the ReactDOM bindings will actually take place. async only - used in front-end application only

title: component-bindings
name: component-bindings
description: Called after plugin and routing initialization to define element and dynamic component for one-off component bindings to the DOM. e.g. In development mode, used to render Redux Dev tools. async only - used in front-end application only

Parameter.description: context.bindPoints MUST be an array of binding objects after this hook is called

binding.description: matching a React component module in one of the Reactium built-in webpack contexts (src/app/components or src/app/components/common-ui) e.g. 'DevTools' maps to src/app/components/DevTools

title: dependencies-load
name: dependencies-load
description: Called after init to give an application a change to load async dependencies. Many Domain Driven Design (DDD) artifacts from generated src/manifest.js are loaded on this hook async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

title: dependencies-load
name: dependencies-load
description: Called after init to give an application a change to load async dependencies. Many Domain Driven Design (DDD) artifacts from generated src/manifest.js are loaded on this hook async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

title: init
name: init
description: Called before all other hooks on Reactium application startup. async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

title: plugin-dependencies
name: plugin-dependencies
description:
Called to indicate all bootstrap dependencies should now be loaded, but before application routes have been initialized. There are 2 default registered callback in Reactium core on this hook. 1. (Highest Priority): The generated src/manifest.js dependencies are attached to this hook context (as context.deps). 2. (High Priority): plugin-init hook will be invoked, at which point all Reactium.Plugin registrations will be called.

 Any hooks that registered after Reactium.Plugin will only be useful if they happen to be invoked during the normal runtime operations of the application.  An important exception to this is `routes-init`, which is deferred until after plugins initialize so they may dynamically add routes before Reactium hands off  control to the Router.  async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

Parameter.description: Core attaches generated manifest loaded dependencies to context.deps

title: plugin-ready
name: plugin-ready
description: Called after all plugin registration callbacks have completed and routes have loaded.

title: register-route
name: register-route
description: Called on boot after routes-init, and during runtime operation of the front-end application, whenever a new route is registered. Can be used to augment a router object before it is registered to the router. async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

Parameter.description: the new or updated route, indentified by unique id (route.id)

title: routes-init
name: routes-init
description: Called after plugin-init, to add React Router routes to Reactium.Routing register before the Router component is initialized and finally the application is bound to the DOM. async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

title: sdk-init
name: sdk-init
description: Called after reactium-hooks.js DDD artifacts are loaded, to allow the Reactium SDK singleton to be extended before the init hook.

title: store-create
name: store-create
description: Called after dependencies-load to trigger Redux store creator. async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

Parameter.description: params.server indicate if is store creation on the server, or in the front-end application
Core implementation of this hook will create the Redux store and set it to context.store.

title: zone-defaults
name: zone-defaults
description: Called after dependencies-load by Reactium.Zone.init() for loading default component rendering Zone controls and components. async only - used in front-end or isomorphically when running server-side rendering mode (SSR)

Parameter.description: used to create initial controls and components. controls.filter for default filtering, controls.sort for default sorting, controls.mapper for default mapping and controls.components for initial registered components. zone.js Domain Driven Design (DDD) artifacts from generated src/manifest.js are registered with Reactium.Zone at this time. See Reactium.Zone SDK for runtime operations.

title: useAsyncEffect()
description: Just like React's built-in useEffect, but can use async/await. If the return is a promise for a function, the function will be used as the unmount callback.

Parameter.description: Just like callback provided as first argument of useEffect, but takes as its own first argument a method to see if the component is mounted. This is useful for deciding if your async response (i.e. one that would attempt to change state) should happen.
Deps list passed to useEffect

name: useAsyncEffect

examples.title: Reactium Usage
StandAlone Import
examples.content: import { useAsyncEffect } from '@atomic-reactor/reactium-sdk-core';

examples.title: Wrong Usage

title: useBreakpoint()
description:
Returns string representing the breakpoint size for a given width.

When using the out of the box scss styles in Reactium, a grid system is in place, and is defined by an overridable sass map $breakpoints-max, defined by default as:

$breakpoints-max: ('xs': 640, 'sm': 990, 'md': 1280, 'lg': 1440,'xl': 1600) !default;

Parameter.description: the width to check the breakpoint for. Example for the default $breakpoints-max providing a width of 640 or less will return xs, 990 or less will return sm and so on.

name: useBreakpoint

title: useBreakpoints()
description:
Provides an object describing the maximum width for each breakpoint used in the Reactium grid styles. When using the out of the box scss styles in Reactium, a grid system is in place, and is defined by an overridable sass map $breakpoints-max, defined by default as:

$breakpoints-max: ('xs': 640, 'sm': 990, 'md': 1280, 'lg': 1440,'xl': 1600) !default;

These breakpoint maximums are automatically encoded and added to the stylesheet as :after psuedo-element content property, which can be loaded in the browser and used for in browser responsive behavior. Potentially, this can mean only having to manage your responsive breakpoints in one place (the stylesheet).
name: useBreakpoints

title: useCapability()
description: React hook to get capability object.

Parameter.description: the name/tag of the capability

name: useCapability

title: useCapabilityCheck()
description: React hook to check a list of capabilities. Uses Reactium.Capability.check().

Parameter.description: array of 1 or more capabilities
when true all capabilities must be allowed for current user

name: useCapabilityCheck

title: useDerivedState()
description:
Sometimes you would like to derive state from your component props, and also allow either a prop change, or an internal state change either to take effect. This hook will allow you to create a state object from your component props, and subscribe (by array of object-paths) only to those prop changes you would like to see reflected in a rendering updates to your component state. This hook returns an array similar in nature to the return of React's built-in useState() hook ([state,setState]), with some differences.

  1. The initial value coming from props (on first render) will contain all that was present in the props object passed to it. Note that any values that are not present in your component props on first render, or that which are explicitly subscribed to, will not exist in the returned state element.
  2. The setState callback can receive whole or partial state objects, and will be merged with the existing state.
  3. There is a third element function forceRefresh

Parameter.description: the component props

Array of string object-paths in your component props you would like to update your component state for. By default, this is empty, and if left empty you will get only the initial props, and no updates. Each selected property is shallow compared with the previous version of that prop (not the current state). Only a change of prop will trigger a prop-based update and rerender.
When true, an update to any subscribed object-path on your props will cause all the props to imprint on your component state.

name: useDerivedState

examples.title: Returns
examples.content:
// The hook returns an array containing [state, setState, forceRefresh]
const [state, setState, forceRefresh] = useDerivedState(props, ['path.to.value1', 'path.to.value2']);

examples.title: Usage

title: useDocument()
description: Serves same use-case as useWindow(), but provides context aware document object or undefined, that can be used normally as well as in the react-frame-component within the toolkit.
name: useDocument

title: useEventEffect()
description: React hook to short hand for addEventListener and removeEventLister for one or more callbacks.

Parameter.description: Some event target object (implementing addEventListener and removeEventLister)
Object keys are event names, and Object values are callbacks to be subscribed/unsubscribed.
consistent with React useEffect deps list.

name: useEventEffect

examples.title: EventEffectComponent.js

title: useEventHandle()
description: React hook to create an imperative handle that is also an implementation of EventTarget. Can be used in conjunction with useImperativeHandle (React built-in) or useRegisterHandle/useHandle (Reactium SDK hooks).

Parameter.description: Interface for interacting with your component.

name: useEventHandle

examples.title: EventHandleComponent.js
EventHandleConsumer.js

title: useEventRefs()
name: useEventRefs
description: Like useRefs, creates a single reference object that can be managed using the get/set/del/clear functions, however also an EventTarget object. set/del/clear methods dispatch before-set/set, before-del/del, and before-clear/clear events respectively.

examples.title: Usage

Parameter.description: The DOM element to search for the 'data-focus' element.
Dependencies list passed to useEffect.

examples.title: Reactium Usage
Returns
examples.content: {Array} [focused:Element, setFocused:Function]

title: useFulfilledObject()
name: useFulfilledObject
description: Asyncronous React hook that determines if the supplied object has values for the supplied keys. Useful when you have many useEffect calls and need to know if multiple pieces of the state are set and ready for rendering.

Parameter.description: The object to check.
List of object paths to validate.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: useHandle()
description: React hook to subscribe to a specific imperative handle reference. Useful for having one functional component control another.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'. Identifies the full path to an imperative handle.
the value to use for the handle if it does not exist.

name: useHandle

examples.title: Counter.js
CounterControl.js

title: useHookComponent()
description: A React hook used to define React component(s) that can be overrided by Reactium plugins, using the Reactium.Component.register() function.

Parameter.description: the unique string used to register component(s).
the default React component(s) to be returned by the hook.
variadic list of parameters to be passed to the Reactium hook specified by hookName.

name: useHookComponent

examples.title: parent.js
reactium-hooks.js

title: useIsContainer()
name: useIsContainer
description: React hook that determines if the element is a child of the container. Useful for traversing the DOM to find out if an event or action happened within the specified container.

Parameter.description: The inner most element. Consider this the starting point.
The outer most element. Consider this the destination.

examples.title: Example

title: useRefs()
name: useRefs
description: Creates a single reference object that can be managed using the get/set/del/clear functions.

examples.title: Usage
Proxy Reference Usage

title: useRegisterHandle()
description: React hook to create a new imperative handle reference, similar to useImperativeHandle() except that instead of using React.forwardRef() to attach the handle to a parent compenent ref. A ref is generated for you and is assigned the current value of the callback cb, is registered with Reactium.Handle, and made available to all other components at the object path id.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'. Identifies the full path to an imperative handle.
Function that returns value to be assigned to the imperative handle reference.

Array of values to watch for changes. When changed, your reference will be updated by calling cb again. All Reactium.Handle.subscribe() subscribers will be called on updates, and relevant useHandle() hooks will trigger rerenders.

name: useRegisterHandle

title: useRegisterSyncHandle()
description: React hook to create a new imperative handle reference, similar to useRegisterHandle() except that it returns a sync state object (see useSyncState) and will cause rerenders in the controlled component.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'. Identifies the full path to an imperative handle.
value of the state handle.

name: useRegisterSyncHandle

examples.title: Counter.js
CounterControl.js

title: useRoles()
description: React hook to get roles object. If search is provided, will retrieve a specific role.

Parameter.description: Name, level or object id of the roles to retrieve. If not provide, an object will all roles will be returned.

name: useRoles

title: useScrollToggle()
description: React hook to that returns a control allowing you to enable, disable, or toggle scroll locking on the body element. Also registers the returned handle as BodyScroll. To use the BodyScroll handle, you need only apply useSelectHandle() in one global component. See useSelectHandle() for information on using registered handles.
name: useScrollToggle

examples.title: NPM Usage
examples.content: import { useScrollToggle } from '@atomic-reactor/reactium-sdk-core';

examples.title: Reactium Usage
examples.content: import { useScrollToggle } from 'reactium-core/sdk';

examples.title: Modal.js
LockToggle.js

title: useSelectHandle()
description: React hook to subscribe to updates to state on an imperative handle created by useRegisterSyncHandle. See useRegisterSyncHandle for full example.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'. Identifies the full path to an imperative handle.
object path string or array, or selector function passed the sync state object (see useSyncState); returns seleted state
default selected value (if selector is String or Array)

name: useSelectHandle

title: useSettingGroup()
description: Get and set a group of Actinium settings.

Parameter.description: the setting group id

name: useSettingGroup

examples.title: Usage
Returns

title: useStatus()
name: useStatus

Parameter.description: The initial status of the hook.

description:
Synchronously set a status value that can be checked within a function scope without updating the state of the component. Useful when doing asynchronous activities and the next activity depends on a status of some sort from the previous activity.

Returns [status:String, setStatus:Function, isStatus:Function, getStatus:Function]

status

The current asynchronous status value. (is accurate once per render)

setStatus(status:String, forceRender:Boolean = false)

Set the status value. If forceRender is true, a rerender will be triggered. Beware: forceRender may have unintended consequence and should be used in last status before re-rendering situations only.

isStatus(statuses:Array)

Check if the current status matches the statuses passed.

getStatus()

Get the synchrounous value of the status. This can matter if you need to set and check the value in the same render cycle.

title: useSyncState()
description: Intended to provide an object to get and set state synchrounously, while providing a EventTarget object that can dispatch a 'set' event when the state is updated.

Parameter.description: The initial state.

name: useSyncState

examples.title: SimpleExample
EventTarget
Consumer

title: useWindow()
description: React hook which resolves to the browser or electron window when run in normal context or in the Reactium toolkit. Otherwise will return undefined. This is important particularly when you need to inspect the window inside the react-frame-component (FrameContextConsumer) which sandboxes your component withing the toolkit. Your component will automatically be rendered inside the WindowProvider, which will provide the correct window and document objects. See useWindowSize() for the most important use case.

examples.title: BrowserComponent.js

name: useWindow

title: useWindowSize()
description:
Returns window innerWidth number, innerHeight number, and current breakpoint, and updates on window resizes. When using the out of the box scss styles in Reactium, a grid system is in place, and is defined by an overridable sass map $breakpoints-max, defined by default as:

$breakpoints-max: ('xs': 640, 'sm': 990, 'md': 1280, 'lg': 1440,'xl': 1600) !default;

Parameter.description: defaultWidth, defaultHeight, and debounce delay properties.
Default width returned by the hook when window object is undefined.
Default height returned by the hook when window object is undefined.
Debounce delay to throttle many window resize events, to prevent unnecessary rerenders of your component using this hook.

name: useWindowSize

examples.title: ResponsiveComponent.js

title: useZoneComponents()
description: A React hook used in the Zone component to determine what components should currently be rendered. Useful to observe a zone in another component. If you want to observe to the zone components without necessarily causing a rerender in your component, use Reactium.Zone.getZoneComponents() (to get a list of components in the zone), alone or in combination with Reactium.Zone.subscribe().

Parameter.description: the zone id.

If true, returns the current value of the components in the zone, separate from the reference. Otherwise, returns the ReactiumSyncState object. This can be useful if you wish to use the components value with a non-memoized value.

name: useZoneComponents

examples.title: Example
NoDereference

title: Cache
name: Cache
description: Cache allows you to easily store application data in memory.

title: Cache.clear()
name: Cache.clear
description: Delete all cached values.

Parameter.description: The key to delete. If the value is an {Object} you can use an object path to delete a specific part of the value. The updated value is then returned.

examples.title: Example Usage:
examples.content: Reactium.Cache.clear();

title: Cache.del()
name: Cache.del
description: Delete the value for a given key. Returns {Boolean}.

Parameter.description: The key to delete. If the value is an {Object} you can use an object path to delete a specific part of the value. The updated value is then returned.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Cache.get()
name: Cache.get
description: Retrieves the value for a given key. If the value is not cached null is returned.

Parameter.description: The key to retrieve. If the value is an {Object} you can use an object path for the key. If no key is specified the entire cache is returned.
The default value to return if key is not found.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Cache.keys()
name: Cache.keys
description: Returns an array of the cached keys.

title: Cache.memsize()
name: Cache.memsize
description: Returns the number of entries taking up space in the cache.

title: Cache.merge()
name: Cache.merge
description: Merges the supplied values object with the current cache. Any existing entries will remain in cache. Duplicates will be overwritten unless option.skipDuplicates is true. Entries that would have exipired since being merged will expire upon merge but their timeoutCallback will not be invoked. Returns the new size of the cache.

Parameter.description: Key value pairs to merge into the cache.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Cache.set()
name: Cache.set
description: Sets the value for a given key. If the value is an {Object} and is already cached, you can use an object path to update a specific part of the value. Returns the cached value.

Parameter.description: The key to set. If the key is an object path and the key does not exist, it will be created.
The value to cache.
Remove the value in the specified time in milliseconds. If no timeout value specified, the value will remain indefinitely.
Function called when the timeout has expired. The timeoutCallback will be passed the key and value as arguments.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Cache.size()
name: Cache.size
description: Returns the current number of entries in the cache.

title: Cache.subscribe()
name: Cache.subscribe
description: Subscribe to cache changes that impact a particular key. Returns an unsubscribe function.

Parameter.description: object path of the cache value (array or string)
The callback function to call when impacting changes have been made to the subscribed cache. Changes include any set/put, delete, clear, merge, or expiration that may impact the value you care about.

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Component.register()
name: Component.register
description: Register a React component to be used with a specific useHookComponent React hook. This must be called before the useHookComponent that defines the hook.

Parameter.description: The hook name
component(s) to be output by useHookComponent
precedent of this if Component.register is called multiple times (e.g. if you are trying to override core or another plugin)

parent.js

description: Get a specific imperative handle reference, by object path (id). If id is full object path to the handle, returns a React reference if it exists, otherwise undefined. If id is partial object path, returns object containing one or more references if the path exists, otherwise 'undefined'.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'

Counter.js
CounterControl.js

title: Handle.list()
description: Get full object containing all current reference handles.
name: Handle.list

title: Handle.register()
description: Register an imperative handle reference. See useRegisterHandle() React hook for easier pattern for functional components.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'
React reference created with React.createRef()`` or React.useRef()`.
Update useHandle subscribers of this handle id.

name: Handle.register

examples.title: MyControllableComponent.js

title: Handle.subscribe()
description: Subscribe to changes in imperative handle references (registrations and unregistrations). Returns unsubscribe function.

Parameter.description: callback to be called when a handle is registered or unregistered

examples.title: MyComponent.js

title: Handle.unregister()
description: Unregister an imperative handle reference. See Handle.register() for example usage.

Parameter.description: Array of properties, or . separated object path. e.g. ['path','to','handle'] or 'path.to.handle'

name: Handle.unregister

title: Handle
name: Reactium.Handle
description:
Similar concept to an imperative handle created when using React.forwardRef() and the useImperativeHandle() React hook. Reactium provides the Reactium.Handle object to manage references created in your components to allow imperative control of your component from outside the component. This is used when you wish to change the internal state of your component from outside using a technique other than changing the component props (i.e. declarative control).

This technique makes use of references created with React.createRef() or the useRef() hook for functional components. The developer can then assign the current property of this reference to be an object containing methods or callbacks (i.e. methods that can invoke this.setState() or the update callback returned by useState() hook) that will cause the state of the component to change (and rerender).

By registering this "handle reference" on the Reactium.Handle singleton, other distant components can exercise imperative control over your component.

For developers that prefer the use of React hooks, Reactium provides two hooks for your use: useRegisterHandle() and useHandle() to register and use these handles respectively.

title: Hook.flush()
name: Hook.flush
description: Clear all registered callbacks for a hook.

Parameter.description: the hook name
'async' or 'sync' hooks

title: Hook.list()
name: Hook.list
description: Register a hook callback.

title: Hook.register()
name: Hook.register
description: Register a hook callback.

Parameter.description: the hook name

async function (or returning promise) that will be called when the hook is run. The hook callback will receive any parameters provided to Hook.run, followed by a context object (passed by reference to each callback).
order of which the callback will be called when this hook is run.
the unique id. If not provided, a uuid will be generated

examples.title: Example Usage

title: Hook.registerSync()
name: Hook.registerSync
description: Register a sync hook callback.

function returning promise that will be called when the hook is run. The hook callback will receive any parameters provided to Hook.run, followed by a context object (passed by reference to each callback).
order of which the callback will be called when this hook is run.
the unique id. If not provided, a uuid will be generated

title: Prefs.clear()
description: Clear one or more preferences.

Parameter.description: If specified as an object-path, will unset a specific preference path. Otherwise, all preferences will be cleared.

name: Prefs.clear

examples.title: Example
examples.content:
import Reactium from 'reactium-core/sdk';

Reactium.Prefs.clear();

title: Prefs.get()
description: Get one or more preferences by object path.

Parameter.description: If specified as an object-path, will get a specific preference by this path. Otherwise, all preferences will be returned.
The value to return if the preference has not been set.

name: Prefs.get

examples.title: Example
examples.content:
import Reactium from 'reactium-core/sdk';

const myPref = Reactium.Prefs.get('my.object.path', { someDefault: 'foo' });

title: Prefs.set()
description: Get one or more preferences by object path.

Parameter.description: The object-path to use to set the value.
The value to set to the key.

name: Prefs.set

examples.title: Example

import Reactium from 'reactium-core/sdk';

Reactium.Prefs.set('my.object.path', { value: 'foo' });

title: Pulse.Task
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task
description: Pulse Task object that performs the heavy lifting for the Pulse API.

title: Pulse.Task.ID
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.ID
description: [read-only] The unique ID of the task. Returns: String.

title: Pulse.Task.attempt
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.attempt
description: [read-only] The current attempt for the active task. Returns: Number.

title: Pulse.Task.delay
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.attempt
description: The current attempt for the active task. Returns: Number.

title: Pulse.Task.attempts
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.attempts
description: The number of times a task will retry before it fails. Default: -1. You can set this value after the task has started.

title: Pulse.Task.autostart
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.autostart
description: [read-only] If the task autastarted upon creation. Default: true.

title: Pulse.Task.complete
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.complete
description: [read-only] Relevant only when the repeat property is higher than 1. Returns: Boolean.

title: Pulse.Task.count
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.count
description: [read-only] The current number of times the task has succeeded. Returns: Number.

title: Pulse.Task.error
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.error
description: [read-only] The current error message if applicable. Returns: string.

title: Pulse.Task.failed
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.failed
description: [read-only] Expresses if the current task has reached the maximum attempts. Returns: Boolean.

title: Pulse.Task.now()
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.now
description: Force run the task without waiting for it's delay. If the task is running this is a noop.

title: Pulse.Task.progress
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.progress
description: [read-only] The current amount of the repeat that has been completed. Relevant only when repeat is higher than 1. Returns: 0-1.

title: Pulse.Task.repeat
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.repeat
description: The current number of times to run the task. Returns: Number.

title: Pulse.Task.retry()
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.retry
description: Force a retry of the task. Useful for when you want to manually handle retries within your callback function.

title: Pulse.Task.start()
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.start
description: Start the task. Useful for when you want manually start a task in your callback function.

title: Pulse.Task.status
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.status
description: [read-only] The current status of the task. For comparing the status use the Pulse.ENUMS.STATUS values

examples.title: Example usage:

title: Pulse.Task.stop()
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.stop
description: Stop the task

title: Pulse.Task.timer
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.timer
description: [read-only] The reference to the current setTimeout. This value will change for each task run. Returns: Number.

title: Pulse.get()
name: Pulse.get
description: Retrieve a registered task. Returns a Pulse.Task object.

Parameter.description: The ID of the task.

examples.title: Example usage:
examples.content: const task = Reactium.Pulse.get('MyTask');

title: Pulse.register()
name: Pulse.register
description: Register a new task. The callback function can be any function and supports returning a Promise from the function. If a Promise is rejected, or the callback function returns an Error object or false, a retry will be triggered if possible. In cases where no more retries can be executed, the task will fail.

Parameter.description: The unique ID of the task.
The function to execute when the task is run. The first parameter passed to the callback function will be a reference to the current task object.
The Pulse.Task configuration object.
Number of times to retry a task. By default the task will retry indefinitely.
Start the task when it is registered.
Time in milliseconds before the task is run again. The task will not run again until after it's callback has been executed.
Number of times to repeat the task. Used in determining if the task is complete. A task with -1 as the value will never complete.
Additional parameters to pass to the callback function.

examples.title: Example usage:
Persist

title: Pulse.start()
name: Pulse.start
description: Start a registered task if it is stopped.

Parameter.description: The task unique ID.

examples.title: Example usage:
examples.content: Reactium.Pulse.start('MyTask');

title: Pulse.startAll()
name: Pulse.startAll
description: Start all stopped tasks.

examples.title: Example usage:
examples.content: Reactium.Pulse.startAll();

title: Pulse.stop()
name: Pulse.stop
description: Stop a registered task if it is running.

Parameter.description: The task unique ID.

examples.title: Example usage:
examples.content: Reactium.Pulse.stop('MyTask');

title: Pulse.stopAll()
name: Pulse.stopAll
description: Stop all running registered tasks.

examples.title: Example usage:
examples.content: Reactium.Pulse.stopAll();

title: Pulse.unregister()
name: Pulse.unregister
description: Stop and unregister a task. If the task is running, it's current attempt will resolve before the task is removed.

Parameter.description: The task unique ID.

examples.title: Example usage:

title: Pulse
name: Reactium.Pulse
description:
Simple interface for creating long or short polls.

Motivation

Often is the case where you find yourself sprinkling setTimeout or setInterval all over your code and before you know it, you have so many or rewrite the same structures over and over with a slight twist here and there. The Pulse API is designed to lighten the load on those situations and give a clean interface to easily create and manage polls.

title: Pulse.Task.reset()
name: Reactium.Pulse.Task.reset
description: Resets the task's attempt count and run count. Useful for catastrophic failures in your callback function.

title: Routing.get()
name: Routing.get
description: Get sorted array of all route objects.

title: Routing.register()
description: Dynamically register a new React router route.

Parameter.description:
object to be used as properties of React Router <Route /> component, including:

  1. path - the routing pattern
  2. exact - true/false if the pattern should be matched exactly
  3. component - the React component to render on this route
  4. order - (special) the priority of this route in the list of routes (which route will resolve first)
  5. load - (special) high-order Redux action function (thunk) to run when this route is resolved (should return a promise)
  6. ... any other property <Route /> component accepts

Important Note

Unless called in isomorphic javascript (ie. code executed both in browser and in node.js), these routes will not yield Server-Side-Rendered html in SSR mode. The browser will still render the route correctly (will not break the page), however the server will deliver a 404 status code on cold loads of the page (i.e. hard-refresh of the browser).

name: Routing.register

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Routing.unregister()
name: Routing.unregister
description: Unregister an existing route, by id. Note: You can not unregister the 'NotFound' component. You can only replace it using the registering a NotFound component with Reactium.Component.register().

Parameter.description: the route id

examples.title: Example Usage:

title: Utils.registryFactory()
description:
Creates a new instance of a simple registry object. Useful for creating an SDK registry for allowing plugins to register "things". e.g. components that will render inside a component, callbacks that will run.

More documentation needed:

  • register method: used to register an object on registry
  • unregister method: used to unregister an object on registry
  • list property: getter for list of registered objects
  • protect method: called to prevent overwriting an id on registry
  • unprotect method: called to again allow overwriting on id
name: Utils.registryFactory

examples.title: Basic Reactium Usage
Basic Core Usage
examples.content:
import SDK from '@atomic-reactor/reactium-sdk-core';
export default SDK.Utils.registryFactory('MyRegistry');

title: Utils.splitParts()
description: Breaks formatted string (or array of strings), into flat array of parts/nodes, inserting an object in array in the place of %key%. Useful for tokenizing a translation string, and getting an array that can easily be mapped into React components. Returns an object with replace and value methods. Call replace(key,value) method (chaining) as many times as necessary to replace all tokens. Call value() method to get the final array of Part objects. Call reset() to reset the SlipParts object to the original string without replacements for reuse.

Parameter.description: String containing tokens like %key% to be replaced.

replace.description: when calling replace(key,value), the token %${key}% will be replaced with an Part object key->value pair.
the value to use in the key->pair replacement

name: Utils.splitParts

title: Reactium.AppContext
name: Reactium.AppContext
description: A Registry used for top-level React wrapping context provider, such as Redux or Theme. See Registry for full details on Registry methods / properties. Use this to register a React context provider, as well as any properties that are passed to the context.

Parameter.description: get list of most recent (or highest order) registered objects, filtering out unregistered or banned objects.
reg.register(id,data) pass an identifier and a data object to register the object. The identifier will be added if it is not already registered (but protected) and not banned.

reg.unregister(id) pass an identifier to unregister an object. When in HISTORY mode (default), previous registration will be retained, but the object will not be listed. In CLEAN mode, the previous registrations will be removed, unless protected.

register.description: the id of the data object to be registered

Provider.description: the context provider. This provider must be a React component that will render children.

examples.title: reactium-hooks.js

title: Registry
name: Registry
description:
Reactium uses a number of registry objects used to registering all sorts of objects that will be used elsewhere in the framework. New registry objects are generally instanciated as singletons on the overall SDK.

There are many registry objects attached by default to the SDK, and developers can create new ones using Utils.registryFactory().

Parameter.description: get Object keyed by id of most recent (or highest order) registered objects, filtering out unregistered or banned objects.
get list of most recent (or highest order) registered objects, filtering out unregistered or banned objects.
get list of all historically registrated objects, even duplicates, ordered by order property of object (defaults to 100).
get list of protected registrations ids
get list of all existing registered objects ids that have been subsequently unregistered.
get list of all banned objects ids.
get current mode (Default Utils.Registry.MODES.HISTORY)
reg.get(id,defaultValue) pass the identifier of an object get that object from the registry. Optionally provide a default value if the id doesn't exist in the registry.
pass the identifier of an object to see if it has been protected
pass the identifier of an object to see if it has been registered
pass the identifier of an object to see is NOT registered.
pass the identifier of an object to see if it has been banned

reg.ban(id) pass the identifier of an object to ban. Banned objects can not be registered and will not be show in list. Useful when you have code that needs to preempt the registration of an object from code you do not control. E.g. a plugin is introducing undesireable or disabled functionality
reg.cleanup(id) pass the identifier of an object to be purged from historical registrations (i.e. free up memory) Automatically performed in mode Utils.Registry.CLEAN
reg.protect(id) pass the identifier of an object to protect. Protected objects can not be overridden or cleaned up.
reg.register(id,data) pass an identifier and a data object to register the object. The identifier will be added if it is not already registered (but protected) and not banned.
reg.unprotect(id) pass an identifier to unprotect an object

reg.unregister(id) pass an identifier to unregister an object. When in HISTORY mode (default), previous registration will be retained, but the object will not be listed. In CLEAN mode, the previous registrations will be removed, unless protected.
reg.flush() clear all registrations. Resets registry to newly constructed state.
reg.subscribe(cb,id) Adds a callback to indicate changes to the registry. Callback is called on register, unregister, protect, unprotect, ban, cleanup, and flush. Returns unsubscribe function.
reg.unsubscribe(id) unsubscribe a subscriber by id
reg.unsubscribeAll() unsubscribe all subscribers to changes made on the registry

register.description: the id of the data object to be registered

subscribe.description: Callback to be invoked on changes to the registry.
optional id of the callback, if you want to invoke unsubscribe manually by id, instead of the callback returned from subscribe method

unsubscribe.description: the id of the subscriber to unsubscribe

title: Zone
name: Zone
description:
Component used to identify a "zone" in your application where any arbitrary components will render. Plugin components registered for this zone will dynamically render in the zone. Plugins can be registered statically in Reactium by creating a plugin.js file that exports a component definition (arcli plugin component to generate boilerplate for one), or using the Reactium SDK Reactium.Zone.addComponent() call.

See also the Zone SDK for filtering, sorting, or mapping over plugin components for a zone.

To generate an exportable plugin module, use the arcli plugin module command.

Parameter.description: Identifier of the zone where plugin components will be rendered.

When true, will provide a components property to children of Zone instead of rendering plugin components directly as siblings. This is useful when you wish to make plugin components available, but take more control over how they render.

Example Passthrough Usage: Using the jsx-parser module, components could be provided to a JSXParser component, and the actual render of those components could be dictated by a string of JSX and data context provided by a CMS.
any number of arbitrary parameters (variadic) can be provided to the Zone, and will be passed automatically as props on your plugin components when they are rendered.

examples.title: PageHeader.js
src/app/components/plugin-src/MyHeaderPlugin/index.js
src/app/components/plugin-src/MyHeaderPlugin/MyHeaderWidget.js

description: Wrap this around string literals to make them translateable with gettext Poedit utility. Run arcli i18n to extract strings to src/reactium-translations/template.pot by default.

Parameter.description: the text to be translated. Important: this should not be a variable. It must be a string literal, or arcli i18n command will not be able to locate the string. This string may not be an ES6 template literal.

examples.title: Usage

title: _n()
description: Wrap this around string literals to make them translateable with gettext Poedit utility. Run arcli i18n to extract strings to src/reactium-translations/template.pot by default.
name: _n

Parameter.description: the singular form text to be translated. Important: this should not be a variable. It must be a string literal, or arcli i18n command will not be able to locate the string. This string may not be an ES6 template literal.

the plural form text to be translated. Important: this should not be a variable. It must be a string literal, or arcli i18n command will not be able to locate the string. This string may not be an ES6 template literal.
the number related to singular or plural string
